comment: This is bananas foster in liquid form. Super sweet, heavy on the caramel throughout. And I love it.
Caramel, banana, and vanilla on the nose.  Some cherry wood, vanilla, and brown sugar on the palette.  Mellow and smooth.
Full and sweet, but not over powering sweet. This is probably my new favorite whiskey.

Raisins, vanilla and a little banana on the nose. Vanilla pudding, dark toast and spices on the palate. Like a more refined, mellow version of the regular Stranahan's. 

Review of batch 002

The palate is a cacophony of red fruits, and even a pseudo-sherry flavor (how did that get there?).  There's a tanginess that emerges in the mid-palate that suggests that perhaps things will turn out all right.  However, this is soon subsumed by the deluge of cloying sweetness.  Simply not to my taste.
A nose with subtle hints of multi-cat litterbox; followed by Windex overtones with just a hint of compost-bin scrapings. Just kidding, this is actually one of my all-time favorites.
One of the first malts I've ever had that I vastly prefer on the rocks.
Coffee and chocolate with great finish
Spicy and full-bodied. The flavors sit for a while and there is a long-heat in your chest.

So funny that earlier this evening I also had a Flying Dog Dogtoberfest, then ordered this much later at another bar, not knowing the distillery and the brewery were commonly known.  My rating of this bourbon and that beer were both the same: very good, 3.5.  Nothing outstanding.
What a beautiful aroma. Relaxing cherry. Fantastic notes of flower and fruit from start to finish. A really great, and affordable drink.
Very smooth and rich in flavor. Finishes quickly with cinnamon and vanilla.

An amazing expression for such a young American single malt. Virgin oak maturation comes out big in both the nose and taste, but a dab of water and 10m in the glass and you have the perfect dessert whiskey. Melts in your mouth with oak, cake, and nuts powering through
Mellow and tasty. Maybe not worth the extra cost over the standard Stranahan's

Smells very fruity, sweet, a little minty. Caramel granny smith apple. Fantastic nose. On the palate, very light, smooth, but a nice herbal and spice kick at the end that hits the back of the throat. Slight bitterness that lingers. Not as malty as I expected, this would pass as a rye. 5/7/18

Nose - Sweet malt, almost bourbon-like vanilla, toasted white bread, faint toasted/baked apple with skin/core.

Taste - Sweet spicy apple/pear cider, lightly drying cinnamon oak, faint creamy apple custard, hint of flamed orange zest, light fruity bitterness.

Finish - Lingering buttery creamy apple/orange custard, charred cinnamon bitterness, white peper heat, lingering sweet orange/vanilla simple that leans a bit splenda-ish.

Score - 72/100

Final Thoughts - This was quite interesting on the nose as if I think if I nosed it blind, I would almost peg it as a high barley content bourbon. It has a very sweet vanilla bourbon-like notes, but a yeasty malty toasted bread is also very strongly present too. Mouthfeel is great in that it is somehow creamy/buttery, yet drying at the same time. It's quite strange, but very pleasant. Not sure I'm a huge fan of the combination on the palate, but it's got a nice orchard fruit/custard vibe to it, but what throws it off is that there's this overall splenda-like sweetness from start to finish. If this is considered a step up from their "standard" offering, I think I'll pass on them as a whole. This is a dram that I'd drink if my only other options were things like Dewar's White or A.D. Laws.

Stranahan's hasn't let me down yet. I love their entry-level whiskey, as well as the single barrel incarnation of it that I tried; this, their ostensible step up from the flagship, is every bit as good, if not slightly better. The mint and dark chocolate notes that seem to be hallmarks of the house style come across even more boldly here, especially the mint. There's a deep, dark fruitiness, too - not quite into dried fig territory yet, but definitely raisiny. The finish is lovely, ever so slightly hot, with the minty freshness taking a long ride into a mountain sunset. Excellent whiskey, well worth the $60 I paid for the bottle.
Best of regular and sherry. A little smoke, less heat.
Unique. Fruity. New wood barrel taste, slight charcoal. Light overall.

Absolutely fantastic and one of the most unique bottles to come out of America in my opinion. Tons and tons of banana on the nose, which translates almost to a banana's foster on the taste with banana, brown sugar, and maybe a slight bit of chocolate or coffee. 

Regardless, this is a bottle I always will come back to and will have a place on my shelf. Just wow.

Nose: Fruit, Caramel, cotton candy, chocolate, 

Taste: chocolate, maple, more fruit, sweet cigar smoke.

Nose. Slight smoke with a good sweetness. Spices on the nose are bright and fun. Cinnamon and brown sugar are very prominant. 
Taste: A light sweet smokey flavor gives way to a wonderful spiced pound cake flavor. Reminding me of a wonderful spiced dessert during the holidays.
I absolutely love this whiskey. It’s delightfully sweet, spicy, and full of oak, vanilla and caramel. It gets better every time I have it.
Musty barn/hay and some peppery notes on the nose with a little red fruit hiding in the back. Sour bread and barrel spice on the taste.
much better with a few drops of water

Went and visited a friend in Colorado who knows I am a big bourbon fan. He had picked up a bottle not realizing this wasn’t a bourbon but a single malt. Decided to give it a try and was pleasantly surprised. Had a really nice flavor profile, got hints of banana and caramel. Had a nice finish and was very drinkable. Inspired me to take a trip to the distillery and try a few of their others. A bit pricy (about $70 a bottle) but not over the top for a hand bottled craft whisky. Definitely worth a try.
I get peppermint all the way through. Long finish. Coats the tongue. Very nice.

Wanted a change of pace and figured I'd give this American Single malt a try! While a single malt (100% malted barley), it is aged like a Bourbon in new #3 char American oak barrels. At 94 proof, it's also proofed like a Bourbon. Based on this I am expecting a cross between a classic single malt and a Bourbon. This is exactly what you get!. Upon entry you get classic malt notes with a hint of smoke, that quickly moves to rich caramel and vanilla spice. Mid pallette has some honey and smoked marshmallow, almost like a smore! Finish is pretty long and has some more sweet spice with a hint of sweet mint.
Really nice pour! It's definitely a sweet whiskey (even for a Bourbon drinker) but makes for a great change of pace! Would I pay $75 for this bottle? No. Would I get another $9 pour? Absolutely! 3.5/5

A perfect Christmas dram, reminding me of winter on the porch watching the snow fall.

Loads of caramel sweetness, almost cola-like, with a nice tea loaf spicyness.
Dark caramel and molasses on the nose. Great subtle spice between those flavors on the tongue. Super smooth, rich body. Magnificent. Caramel sticks around for the tail, but it's not too sweet at all.
Good but I don't think its worth the extra money above and beyond the regular yellow label.

It’s probably worth noting that this pour has been exposed to prolonged cool outside air. The color is on the darker side for a Scotch. The nose has a huge chocolate covered cherry aroma.  Subtle cherry notes on first sip with mild oak on the finish. The mouthfeel is full, but not quite to a Highland 18 level. This is a nice, moderately-rich, unique option to a standard Scotch. 3.76.

Thanks to @The_Rev , I got a generous sample to try this.  With my regular trips to Denver, I’ve been meaning to actually visit Stranahan’s, but my schedule generally only involves office to hotel back to office.  Till then, this will have to do.  I believe that the most noteworthy American single malt distilleries are Westland and Stranahan’s...the others can’t even come close.  Products like this will just continue to get better as it ages more in the barrels.  This one brings flavors of brown sugar, some mint, marzipan.  Well made, but young...can do with some age to take off the roughness and slightly bitter finish.  Till this ages, I’m going to instead try their sherry cask, which I’ve heard is better, but what I’d really like to get my hands on is their annual Snowflake, which is reportedly amazing enough to have lines overnight.  Thanks @The_Rev for the pour!

Meh. 

Not a fan of Stranahan’s at all. Thought a “diamond” upgrade might add something, but it fell flat. If you like the spicy raw taste of a rye, maybe this is good for you. 

Not smooth, may mix well.

The nose is barrel char and fruity notes - banana?  Rubbing alcohol.

On the palate this is very chocolatey, bitter dark chocolate, rubbing alcohol, char, dry oak.

The finish is long with bitter chocolate, wood, and grass.

Some of the more bitter flavors run a little too wild in the end for my taste, but I can appreciate this in that it's different.

Edit: I normally don't add water to stuff below the mid 50s ABV, but I did in this case, and it makes a world of difference- the nose becomes very malty, with hints of spice, and a little bitter chocolate.  The change in taste is even more dramatic.  The barley malt really jumps forward, and the bitter chocolate notes take a back seat.  It has a nice spice, somewhere between ground ginger and white pepper, and develops a sour apple character.

The finish is spice, malt, oak, and just a hint of baking chocolate.

I would not drink this again without water, but with it, it's almost a different spirit.
Full bodied barrel, chocolate, and spice notes really enhance an already great small batch single malt.
Just about as good as it gets, smooth and delicious
continuous taste roller coaster. Spice, oak, chocolate, dried fruits, and on and on.
Needs to mature more, flavors are overtaken by the alcohol, needs better balance.  Overpriced for what it is.  Stick with the original Stranahans.
It’s got the funk. I like the funk. Batch 27.

Very smooth overall. Has a reminiscence of a Highland scotch but primarily American whiskey. Light wood and tobacco with a hint of apple on the palate. Finish reminds me of a cinnamon apple dessert; slight spice but plenty of sweet.
Very nice notes of caramel, slight minty undertone. An American single malt that has a bourbon crossover. Nothing exceptional but very pleasant to drink
All bananas foster on the nose, excellent aroma. Smells creamy and sweet! Taste is a slight letdown, cold remedy- menthol-lite. Not my jam
Sweet up front with a hint of spice to finish up

Hot nose with notes of vanilla, Barrell char, cigars and rolled grains.
Surprisingly sweet front with lots of warmth following.  Some cacao, tobacco and oak. 
Opened up a little with a few drops of water revealing more of the malt, but still very warming

Nose: Peppermint, candied nuts

Palate: Cinnamon, caramel, and a sweet smoke. Slightly dry mouthfeel

Finish: Medium with lingering spice
